name: Creamy One Pan Spinach Gnocchi
description: Quick and creamy one-pan gnocchi in a coconut cream sauce with sun-dried tomatoes, garlic, and spinach — completely vegan and ready in 20 minutes
author: Kimberley

Fridge.text: 2 tbsp cream cheese, vegan or regular

Pantry.text: 55 g sun-dried tomatoes, finely chopped (oil packed)
2 tbsp nutritional yeast (or finely grated parmesan)

steps: Warm {olive oil} and {butter} in a wide skillet over medium heat. Add {onion} and {garlic}, cook for 2-3 minutes until fragrant.

Pour in {coconut cream} and whisk in {cream cheese} until smooth. Simmer 2-3 minutes to gently reduce. Stir in {sun-dried tomatoes}, {nutritional yeast}, {Italian seasoning}, {pepper}, and a pinch of {salt}.

Add {gnocchi} and stir well. Cover and cook 3-4 minutes, stirring once or twice, until tender and the sauce is silky. If the sauce tightens too much, add splashes of {water} as needed. If it's too loose, let it bubble uncovered to thicken.
Stir in {spinach} until wilted. Mix in {lemon} juice if using. Taste and adjust seasoning.
serving_suggestions: Serve with a drizzle of oil from the sun-dried tomatoes.

name: Creamy Vegan Mushroom Soup
description: Rich and creamy mushroom soup perfect for batch cooking and freezing
author: James
notes: For a deeper, more umami flavour, add a splash of dry white wine after cooking the onions and let it reduce before adding the stock. If you have dried porcini (Steinpilze), soak a small handful in warm water for 20 minutes, chop them up and add them along with their soaking liquid for incredible depth. The soup keeps well in the fridge for 3-4 days and also freezes beautifully.

Fresh.text: 1 medium floury potato (about 150g), peeled and cubed
1 tsp fresh thyme (or ½ tsp dried)

steps: Heat {olive oil} in a large pot over medium-high heat. Add {mushrooms} and cook for about 8 minutes until they've released their liquid and turned golden brown. Set aside a small handful for garnish if you like.
Lower the heat to medium, add a little more oil if needed, and cook {onion} for about 5 minutes until soft and translucent.
Add {garlic} and {thyme}, stir for about a minute until fragrant.
Add {potato} cubes and {vegetable stock}. Bring to a boil, then reduce to a simmer and cook for about 15 minutes, until the potato is completely tender.
Stir in {oat cream} and {soy sauce}.
Blend the soup using a stick blender until smooth and creamy. If you set some {mushrooms} aside earlier, stir them back in now for a bit of texture.
Season with {salt}, {pepper}, and a squeeze of {lemon} juice. The lemon really lifts the flavour.
Serve with fresh {parsley} on top and some crusty bread on the side.
serving_suggestions: Serve with crusty bread for dipping. Add a swirl of extra oat cream and a drizzle of truffle oil for a fancy touch. Great with a side salad for a complete meal.

name: Pain d'Épice
description: Traditional French spiced honey cake with warming spices
author: James
notes: This delicious French spice bread is best enjoyed the next day when the flavours have had time to develop. It keeps well wrapped in foil for up to a week. The spice mix typically includes cinnamon, green aniseed, star anise, nutmeg, coriander seeds, cloves and ground ginger, but you can also use a pre-made pain d'épices spice blend if available.

Spices.text: 2 tsp spice mix (cinnamon, green aniseed, star anise, grated nutmeg, coriander seeds, cloves, ground ginger)

steps: Preheat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan).
In a large bowl, mix together {brown sugar}, {flour}, {honey}, {baking soda}, {orange blossom water}, {spice mix}, and {milk} until well combined and smooth.
Pour the batter into a greased rectangular baking tin (about 20cm x 10cm).
Bake for 45 minutes, or until a skewer inserted into the center comes out clean.
Let cool in the tin for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely.
serving_suggestions: Slice and enjoy with butter, or serve with tea or coffee. Even better the next day when the flavours have mellowed and the texture becomes more moist. Store wrapped in foil to keep fresh.

name: Creamy Pumpkin & Potato Curry
description: Warming vegan curry perfect for batch cooking and meal prep
author: James
notes: If you like a bit of heat, add a chopped chilli or some chilli flakes in step 2. A handful of spinach stirred in at the end is a nice addition. Keeps well in the fridge for 3–4 days and actually tastes even better the next day!
steps: Heat {oil} in a large pot over medium heat. Add {onion} and cook for about 5 minutes until soft.
Add {garlic}, {ginger}, {curry paste}, {cumin}, and {turmeric}. Stir and cook for another minute until fragrant.
Add {pumpkin} and {potato} cubes and stir everything together so they're coated in the spices.
Pour in {coconut milk} and {vegetable stock}. Give it a good stir and bring to a gentle boil.

Reduce the heat, cover, and let it simmer for about 20–25 minutes, stirring occasionally, until both the {pumpkin} and {potatoes} are tender. The floury {potatoes} will start to break down and thicken the sauce beautifully.
Season with {salt} and {pepper}, then serve over rice (or with naan) topped with fresh {coriander} and a squeeze of {lime}.
serving_suggestions: Serve over basmati rice or with warm naan bread. Top with fresh coriander and a squeeze of lime. Great for meal prep – portion into containers for easy weeknight dinners throughout the week.

name: Silky Smooth Hummus
description: Silky smooth hummus with the perfect creamy texture
author: James
notes: Use warm chickpeas, as they're softer and easier to blend. The ice cubes are not optional! The cold shock against the warm chickpeas aerates the hummus beautifully. Don't add olive oil to the base mixture. The tahini has plenty of fat. Olive oil goes on top when serving. The hummus keeps well in the fridge for up to 3 days.

Spices.text: Optional: pinch of cumin, paprika, sumac, or za'atar

steps: Soak {chickpeas} overnight in plenty of water with 1 teaspoon of {bicarbonate of soda}.

Drain and rinse the {chickpeas}. Place them in a pan with the second teaspoon of {bicarbonate of soda} and cook on medium heat for a few minutes. Add enough water to cover them by a few centimeters, bring to a boil, and cook for 20 to 40 minutes until they're really soft with no bite at all. Skim off any foam and loose skins as they cook.
Drain {chickpeas} over a bowl, saving the cooking water.
While the {chickpeas} are still warm, put them into a food processor with {tahini}, {garlic}, {lemon} juice, {ice cubes}, 2 tablespoons of the reserved chickpea water, and a good pinch of {salt}.

Blitz until smooth, then taste and adjust. You might need more {tahini}, {garlic}, {lemon}, {salt}, or chickpea water. Don't be shy about adding more {tahini}. Blitz for a few minutes at least until it's really smooth and creamy.
Transfer to a bowl, cover the surface with cling film, and let it rest for at least 30 minutes.
Serve drizzled with good {olive oil} and a squeeze of {lemon}. Optionally sprinkle with {cumin}, {paprika}, {sumac}, or {za'atar} for extra flavour.
serving_suggestions: Drizzle with your best olive oil and add a squeeze of fresh lemon. Sprinkle with cumin, paprika, sumac, or za'atar. Serve with warm pita bread, fresh vegetables, or use as a sandwich spread. For the tahini, Al Arz is a great brand that's not too bitter.

name: Classic British Scones
description: Light and fluffy vegan scones perfect for afternoon tea
author: James
notes: Keep the margarine cold – this helps create a flaky texture. Don't overwork the dough, just bring it together gently. Best eaten fresh on the day, but they freeze well too. Just defrost at room temperature and reheat in a hot oven for a few minutes.

Fridge.text: 150ml plant milk (oat or soy work best)
A little extra plant milk for glazing

steps: Preheat the oven to 220°C / 200°C fan / Gas 7 and lightly grease a large baking tray.
Whisk together {flour}, {baking powder}, and {salt} so the raising agent is evenly distributed.
Using your fingertips, rub the cold {margarine} into the {flour} until the mixture resembles fine breadcrumbs.
Stir in {sugar}. Add most of the {plant milk} and mix to form a soft and slightly sticky dough. If it's a little dry, add more {milk} until you get the right consistency.
Turn out onto a floured work surface and knead very lightly. Pat out into a round about 2cm thick.
Use a 5cm cutter to stamp out rounds and place on the baking tray. Lightly knead together any remaining dough and stamp out more scones to use it all up.
Brush the tops with a little {plant milk}.
Bake for 12-15 minutes until well risen and golden.
Cool on a wire rack. Serve with jam and vegan butter, or vegan whipped cream if you're feeling fancy!
serving_suggestions: Serve warm with jam and vegan butter. For a traditional cream tea, add vegan whipped cream. Try adding dried fruit or a pinch of cinnamon to the dough for a twist.

name: Vegan Banana Bread
description: Moist and delicious banana bread made with simple plant-based ingredients
author: James
notes: Use very ripe bananas with lots of brown spots for the best flavour and natural sweetness. The banana bread keeps well wrapped in foil for 3-4 days at room temperature, or can be frozen for up to 3 months. For extra indulgence, fold in some chocolate chips or chopped walnuts before baking.
steps: Preheat the oven to 180°C (160°C fan). Spray a 9×5 inch (23×13cm) loaf pan with nonstick spray, then dust with flour.
In a large mixing bowl, roughly mash {bananas}. Add {light brown sugar}, {oil}, {vanilla}, and {unsweetened plant milk}, and whisk to incorporate.
Sift in {flour}, {baking soda}, {salt}, and {cinnamon}, and use a wooden spoon to mix until just combined. Don't overmix.
Transfer the batter to your prepared pan, and top with extra {banana} slices.
Bake for about 45 minutes, then cover with foil and bake for 10-15 minutes longer, until a toothpick inserted in the center comes out with just a couple of crumbs.
Let cool in the pan for 10 minutes, then turn out onto a wire rack to cool completely before slicing.
serving_suggestions: Enjoy warm with vegan butter, or toasted the next day. Delicious for breakfast with coffee or as an afternoon snack. Try spreading with peanut butter or almond butter for extra protein.
